tit.cmt: ７行目のJurakutei(聚楽亭)と区別するため(聚楽第)を挿入

sen.j: 聚楽第（じゅらくだい／じゅらくてい）は、安土桃山時代に豊臣秀吉が京都の内野（平安京の大内裏跡、現在の京都市上京区にあたる）に建設した大邸宅。
sen.e: Jurakudai (or Jurakutei) was a large residence built by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI in Uchino, Kyoto (the site of the Outer Palace Precincts in Heiankyo, present-day Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City) during the Azuchi-Momoyama period.
sen.cmt: terms欄のHeian Palaceを削除。Daidairi/Greater Palaceを削除。the Outer Palace Precinctsに書き換え。
sen.e: Jurakudai (or Jurakutei) was a large residence built by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI in Uchino, Kyoto (the site of the Outer Palace Precincts in Heiankyo, present-day Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City) during the Azuchi-Momoyama period.

Jurakudai (or Jurakutei) was a large residence built by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI in Uchino, Kyoto (the site of the Outer Palace Precincts in Heiankyo, present-day Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City) during the Azuchi-Momoyama period.

sen.j: 聚楽亭（じゅらくてい）ともいわれる。
sen.e: Also called Jurakutei (聚楽亭).
Also called Jurakutei.
Also called Jurakutei.

sen.j: 堀をめぐらした一種の城であり、聚楽城（じゅらくじょう）ともいわれる。
sen.e: It is a kind of castle with a moat, and thus sometimes called Juraku-jo Castle.
It is a kind of castle with a moat, and thus sometimes called Juraku-jo Castle.
It is a kind of castle with a moat, and thus sometimes called Juraku-jo Castle.

sen.j: 聚楽第は関白になった秀吉の政庁兼邸宅として1586年（天正14年）2月に着工され、翌1586年9月には完成。
sen.e: The construction of Jurakudai began in February 1586, as an office and an official residence of Hideyoshi, who became Kampaku, a chief councillor to the Emperor, and completed in September 1586.

The construction of Jurakudai began in February 1586, as an office and an official residence of Hideyoshi, who became Kampaku (chief advisor to the emperor), a chief councillor to the Emperor, and completed in September 1586.

The construction of Jurakudai began in February 1586, as an office and an official residence of Hideyoshi, who became Kanpaku (chief advisor to the emperor), a chief councilor to the Emperor, and completed in September 1586.

sen.j: 九州征伐を終えた秀吉が大坂より移り、ここで政務をみた。
sen.e: After Hideyoshi conquered Kyushu, he moved into Jurakudai from Osaka to administer political affairs.
sen.cmt: terms欄のKyushu Campaignをconquered Kyushuに書き換え。３０行目にKyushu campaignを使用。
sen.e: After Hideyoshi conquered Kyushu, he moved into Jurakudai from Osaka to administer political affairs.
After Hideyoshi conquered Kyushu, he moved into Jurakudai from Osaka to administer political affairs.

sen.j: 1588年5月9日（旧暦天正16年4月14日）には後陽成天皇の行幸を迎えてこれを饗応している。
sen.e: In May 9, 1588, he welcomed the visit of the Emperor Go-Yozei and entertained him in Jurakudai.
On May 9, 1588, he was visited by Emperor Go-Yozei and entertained him in Jurakudai.
sen.cmt: welcomed the visit of->was visited by
sen.e: On May 9, 1588, he was visited by Emperor Go-Yozei and entertained him in Jurakudai.

sen.j: また天正少年使節や徳川家康の謁見もここで行われた。
sen.e: Also, he gave an audience to Tensho Shonen Shisetsu (Boys' Envoys to Europe during the Tensho era) and Ieyasu TOKUGAWA in Jurakudai.
Also, he gave an audience to Tensho Shonen Shisetsu (Boys' Envoys to Europe during the Tensho era) and Ieyasu TOKUGAWA in Jurakudai.
Also, he gave an audience to Tensho Shonen Shisetsu (Boys' Envoys to Europe during the Tensho era) and Ieyasu TOKUGAWA in Jurakudai.

sen.j: 聚楽第は瓦には金箔を貼るなど大変贅沢なものだったという。
sen.e: Jurakudai was supposedly extremely luxurious with its tiles covered with golden leaf.
Jurakudai was supposedly extremely luxurious with its tiles covered with golden leaf.
Jurakudai was supposedly extremely luxurious with its tiles covered with golden leaf.

sen.j: 「第」（＝ 邸）とあるが、天守を持つ本丸を中心に二の丸などの曲輪を持ち、堀を巡らしており、実際は平城であった。
sen.e: Although being called "-dai (i.e. tei)" (house), Jurakudai was in fact a castle on a plain, since it included several enclosed areas such as donjon with a castle tower in the center and a secondary enclosure around it, and was surrounded with a moat.
sen.cmt: terms欄のTenshuをa castle towerに、Hommaruをdonjonに、Kuruwaをenclosed areasに、Ninomaruをa secondary enclosureに書き換え。
sen.e: Although being called "-dai" (meaning tei/house), Jurakudai was in fact a castle on a plain, since it included several enclosed areas such as a donjon with a castle tower in the center and a secondary enclosure around it, and was surrounded with a moat.

Although being called "-dai" (meaning tei/house), Jurakudai was in fact a castle on a plain, since it included several enclosed areas such as a donjon with a castle tower in the center and a secondary enclosure around it, and was surrounded with a moat.
sen.cmt: スペースの重複を削除

sen.j: 邸内には側近をはじめ千利休などの屋敷も作られた。
sen.e: Within Jurakudai, houses for Hideyoshi's aides, SEN no Rikyu, etc. were built.
Within Jurakudai, houses for Hideyoshi's aides, SEN no Rikyu et al. were built.
Within Jurakudai, houses for Hideyoshi's aides, SEN no Rikyu et al. were built.

sen.j: 1587年10月に北野大茶会が催された北野神社社頭はこの聚楽第のあった内野からほど近い土地にある。
sen.e: Kitano Temman-gu Shrine, where the Kitano Grand Tea Ceremony was held in October 1587, is located in the place nearby Uchino, where Jurakudai resided in.
Kitano Temman-gu Shrine, where the Kitano Grand Tea Ceremony was held in October 1587, is located nearby Uchino, where Jurakudai was.
Kitano Tenman-gu Shrine, where the Kitano Grand Tea Ceremony was held in October 1587, is located nearby Uchino, where Jurakudai was.

sen.j: 1591年12月に秀吉が関白職を甥の豊臣秀次に譲ると聚楽第も秀次のものとなり、その際後陽成天皇を再び迎えている。
sen.e: In December 1591, when Hideyoshi resigned as Kampaku, his nephew Hidetsugu TOYOTOMI succeeded him as Kampaku together with Jurakudai, thereby welcoming the Emperor Go-Yozei.
In December 1591, when Hideyoshi resigned as Kampaku, his nephew Hidetsugu TOYOTOMI succeeded him as Kampaku and took over Jurakudai, at which time Emperor Go-Yozei visited again.
sen.cmt: together with->and took over; thereby welcoming-> at which time … visited
sen.e: In December 1591, when Hideyoshi resigned as Kanpaku, his nephew Hidetsugu TOYOTOMI succeeded him as Kampaku and took over Jurakudai, at which time Emperor Go-Yozei visited again.

sen.j: 秀吉は隠居後の居所として1594年には伏見城の築城を始めるが、翌1595年に関係が悪化していた秀次を高野山に追放した後切腹を命じるに及んで、聚楽第も破却された。
sen.e: In 1594, Hideyoshi began construction of Fushimi-jo Castle for his residence after his retirement, and in 1595, because of an adverse relationship with Hideyoshi, Hidetsugu was sent to Mt. Koya-san and then ordered to commit suicide, thereafter Jurakudai was demolished.

In 1594, Hideyoshi began construction of Fushimi-jo Castle for his residence after his retirement, and in 1595, because of an adverse relationship with Hideyoshi, Hidetsugu was sent to Mt. Koya-san and then ordered to commit suicide, thereafter Jurakudai was demolished.

In 1594, Hideyoshi began construction of Fushimi-jo Castle for his residence after his retirement, and in 1595, because of an adverse relationship with Hideyoshi, Hidetsugu was sent to Mt. Koya-san and then ordered to commit suicide, thereafter Jurakudai was demolished.

sen.j: 聚楽第の建造物の多くは伏見城内へ移築されたが、西本願寺の飛雲閣、大徳寺の唐門、妙覚寺 (京都市)の大門、妙心寺播桃院玄関など、聚楽第から移築されたという伝承がある建造物も少なくない。
sen.e: Many buildings of Jurakudai were relocated into Fushimi-jo Castle, but some other buildings such as Hiunkaku of Nishi-Hongan-ji Temple, Karamon of Daitoku-ji Temple, Daimon of Myokaku-ji Temple (Kyoto City), and the entrance of Hanto-in of Myoshin-ji Temple, have legends that they were also relocated from Jurakudai.

Many buildings of Jurakudai were relocated into Fushimi-jo Castle, but some other buildings such as Hiunkaku of Nishi-Hongan-ji Temple, Karamon of Daitoku-ji Temple, Daimon of Myokaku-ji Temple (Kyoto City), and the entrance of Hanto-in of Myoshin-ji Temple, are also reported to have been relocated from Jurakudai.
sen.cmt: have legends that they were also->are also reported to have been
sen.e: Many buildings of Jurakudai were relocated into Fushimi-jo Castle, but some other buildings such as Hiunkaku of Nishi-Hongan-ji Temple, Karamon of Daitoku-ji Temple, Daimon of Myokaku-ji Temple (Kyoto City), and the entrance of Hanto-in of Myoshin-ji Temple, are also reported to have been relocated from Jurakudai.

sen.j: 名称
sen.e: Name
Name
Name

sen.j: 聚楽第は、建造中は「内野御構」（うちの おかまい／うちの の おんかまえ）と呼ばれていたことが知られており、その初見は『多聞院日記』天正14年2月27日の条にある「去廿一日ヨリ内野御構普請」。
sen.e: It is known that Jurakudai was once called "Uchino Okamai (or Uchino no Onkamae)" during construction, which first appears in "Tamon-in Nikki" (The Diary of Tamon-in Temple), in the section of February 27, 1586, 'the consctruction of Uchino Okamai began on the last 21st.'

It is known that Jurakudai was once called "Uchino Okamai" (or Uchino no Onkamae) during construction, which first appears in "Tamon-in Nikki" (The Diary of Tamon-in Temple), in the section of February 27, 1586, 'the consctruction of Uchino Okamai began on the last 21st.'

It is known that Jurakudai was once called "Uchino Okamai" (or Uchino no Onkamae) during construction, which first appears in "Tamon-in Nikki" (The Diary of Tamon-in Temple), in the section of February 27, 1586, 'the construction of Uchino Okamai began on the last 21st.'

sen.j: 「聚楽」の名が使われ始めるのは九州征伐から帰還した後のことである。
sen.e: The name "Juraku" began to be used after Hideyoshi came back from the Kyushu campaign.
The name "Juraku" began to be used after Hideyoshi came back from the Kyushu campaign.
The name "Juraku" began to be used after Hideyoshi came back from the Kyushu campaign.

sen.j: 「聚楽」という名の由来については、秀吉が御伽衆の大村由己に書かせた『天正記』のひとつ『聚楽第行幸記』に「長生不老の樂（うたまい）を聚（あつ）むるものなり」とある。
sen.e: As to the origin of the name "Juraku," there is a description of 'the place for gathering (ju) songs and dances (raku) for longevity' in "Jurakudai Gyoko-ki" (The Diary of Visit to Jurakudai) by his aide, Yuko OMURA, one of "Tensho-ki" (The Diary of Tensho).
sen.cmt: terms欄のOtogishuをaideに書き換え。 (The Diary of Tensho)、(The Diary of Visit to Jurakudai)を追加。
sen.e: As to the origin of the name "Juraku," there is a description of 'the place for gathering (ju) songs and dances (raku) for longevity' in "Jurakudai Gyoko-ki" (The Diary of Visit to Jurakudai) written by Hideyoshi's aide, Yuko OMURA, one of "Tensho-ki" (The Diary of Tensho).

As to the origin of the name "Juraku," there is a description of 'the place for gathering (ju) songs and dances (raku) for longevity' in "Jurakudai Gyoko-ki" (The Diary of Visit to Jurakudai) written by Hideyoshi's aide, Yuko OMURA, one of "Tensho-ki" (The Diary of Tensho).

sen.j: これ以外に「聚楽」の出典が見いだせないことから、史家のあいだではこれが秀吉の造語によるものだとする見方が一般的となっている。
sen.e: Since no other sources have been found so far, historians generally believe that the term "Juraku" was created by Hideyoshi.
Since no other sources have been found so far, historians generally believe that the term "Juraku" was created by Hideyoshi.
Since no other sources have been found so far, historians generally believe that the term "Juraku" was created by Hideyoshi.

sen.j: 現在
sen.e: Jurakudai of today
Jurakudai of today
Jurakudai of today

sen.j: 聚楽第は現在では地形にわずかに痕跡をとどめる程度で、整然とした遺構は残っていない。
sen.e: There remains no evident structure of Jurakudai today except that the landscape slightly shows its evidence.
There is no recognizable structure of Jurakudai remaining today, except that the landscape bears its mark.
There is no recognizable structure of Jurakudai remaining today, except that the landscape bears its mark.

sen.j: かろうじて「梅雨の井」跡と伝える史跡が松屋町通下長者町通上ル東入ル東堀町内にあるが聚楽第遺構との確証はない。
sen.e: In Matsuyamachi-dori, Shimo-chojamachi-dori, Agaru, Higashi Iru, Higashihori-cho, there is a historic site supposedly of "Tsuyu-no-I," but there is no evidence to show that it is a remnant of Jurakudai.
sen.cmt: terms欄の住所の記載については「通り」のStreetは不要と考え削除。
sen.e: In Matsuyamachi-dori, Shimo-chojamachi-dori, Agaru, Higashi Iru, Higashihori-cho, there is a historic site supposedly of "Tsuyu-no-I," but there is no evidence to show that it is a remnant of Jurakudai.

In Matsuyamachi-dori, Shimo-chojamachi-dori, Agaru, Higashi Iru, Higashihori-cho, there is a historic site supposedly of "Tsuyu-no-I," but there is no evidence to show that it is a remnant of Jurakudai.

sen.j: また智恵光院通出水通下ルの京都市出水老人デイサービスセンターの北向かい（分銅町）に加藤清正寄贈という庭石も残るがこれも確証はない。
sen.e: In addition, there remains a garden stone supposedly contributed by Kiyomasa KATO in Bundo-cho, to the north of Kyoto City, Demizu, Day Service Center in Chiekoin-dori, Demizu-dori, Sagaru, but there is also no evidence to show that it is a remnant of Jurakudai.
sen.cmt: terms欄の住所の記載については「通り」のStreetは不要と考え削除。
sen.e: In addition, there remains a garden stone supposedly contributed by Kiyomasa KATO in Bundo-cho, to the north of Kyoto City, Demizu, Day Service Center in Chiekoin-dori, Demizu-dori, Sagaru, but there is also no evidence to show that it is a remnant of Jurakudai.

In addition, there remains a garden stone supposedly contributed by Kiyomasa KATO in Bundo-cho, to the north of Kyoto City, Demizu, Day Service Center in Chiekoin-dori, Demizu-dori, Sagaru, but there is also no evidence to show that it is a remnant of Jurakudai.

sen.j: ただし、地名には、「須浜町」「須浜池町」「天秤丸町」「山里町」「北之御門町」「高台院町」「東堀町」などなお当時の名残を色濃く残している。
sen.e: Meanwhile, names of towns such as Suhama-cho, Suhamaike-cho, Tenbinmaru-cho, Yamazato-cho, Kitanogomon-cho, Kodaiin-cho, and Higashihori-cho markedly preserve vestiges of those days.
Meanwhile, names of towns such as Suhama-cho, Suhamaike-cho, Tenbinmaru-cho, Yamazato-cho, Kitanogomon-cho, Kodaiin-cho, and Higashihori-cho markedly preserve vestiges of those days.
Meanwhile, names of towns such as Suhama-cho, Suhamaike-cho, Tenbinmaru-cho, Yamazato-cho, Kitanogomon-cho, Kodaiin-cho, and Higashihori-cho markedly preserve vestiges of those days.

sen.j: また「如水町」「小寺町」「浮田町」「飛弾殿町」「田村備前町」「福島町」「中書町」「直家町」など秀吉騎下の武将の名を冠した地名も多く見られる。
sen.e: Also, there are many towns named after warloads who served under Hideyoshi, such as Nyosui-cho, Kodera-cho, Ukita-cho, Hidadono-cho, Tamura-Bizen-cho, Fukushima-cho, Chusho-cho, and Naoie-cho.
Also, there are many towns named after warloads who served under Hideyoshi, such as Nyosui-cho, Kodera-cho, Ukita-cho, Hidadono-cho, Tamura-Bizen-cho, Fukushima-cho, Chusho-cho, and Naoie-cho.
Also, there are many towns named after warlords who served under Hideyoshi, such as Nyosui-cho, Kodera-cho, Ukita-cho, Hidadono-cho, Tamura-Bizen-cho, Fukushima-cho, Chusho-cho, and Naoie-cho.

sen.j: 浄福寺通中立売通の正親小学校北側に聚楽第跡の石碑が建っている。
sen.e: There is a monument of Jurakudai to the north of Seishin Elementary School in Jofukuji-dori, Nakadachiuri-dori.
sen.cmt: terms欄の住所の記載については「通り」のStreetは不要と考え削除。
sen.e: There is a monument to Jurakudai to the north of Seishin Elementary School in Jofukuji-dori, Nakadachiuri-dori.
There is a monument to Jurakudai to the north of Seishin Elementary School in Jofukuji-dori, Nakadachiuri-dori.

sen.j: なお近年行なわれた調査では堀の跡などが発掘され、金箔瓦なども出土した。
sen.e: Note that in recent investigation, remains of a moat and tiles with golden leaf have been found.
Note that in recent investigation, remains of a moat and tiles with gold leaf have been found.
Note that in recent investigation, remains of a moat and tiles with gold leaf have been found.

sen.j: 二条城羽柴（豊臣）秀吉の「二条新屋敷」（聚楽第の前の秀吉の邸宅）
sen.e: "Nijo Shin-Yashiki"(a residence of Hideyoshi before Jurakudai) of Nijo-jo Castle, Hideyoshi HASHIBA (TOYOTOMI)
"Nijo Shin-Yashiki"(Hideyoshi's before Jurakudai) of Hideyoshi HASHIBA (TOYOTOMI) of Nijo-jo Castle,
"Nijo Shin-Yashiki" (Hideyoshi's before Jurakudai) of Hideyoshi HASHIBA (TOYOTOMI) of Nijo-jo Castle,
